children.text: Glenn Maxwell named Kings XI Punjab captain

Maxwell takes over from Murali Vijay for the tenth edition of the tournament.

Glenn Maxwell has been named captain of Kings XI Punjab for the tenth edition of the Indian Premier League, the franchise confirmed on Friday (March 10). The all-rounder will take over from M Vijay, who was named captain midway through the season last year.

Kings XI finished at the bottom of the table last season with just four wins from 14 games. David Miller started the season as the skipper but was relieved of the leadership role midway.

Maxwell played two matches for Delhi Daredevils in 2012 and then three matches for Mumbai Indians in 2013. He then joined Kings XI in the next season and enjoyed a breakthrough season with 552 runs at an average of 34.5 and a strike rate of 187.75.

His contributions were crucial in the United Arab Emirates leg of the tournament as he gave the team crucial initial wins. They made it to the final of the event before losing to Kolkata Knight Riders in the final.

However, Maxwell's form has dipped in the last two seasons with just 145 and 179 runs, in addition to just two wickets, coming from a total of 22 matches.

Kings XI will start their campaign against Rising Pune Supergiant on April 8 in Indore, their second home venue after Mohali.
Law hopes West Indies players learn from England turnaround

Law rued missed opportunities in the field in the 0-3 ODI series loss against the visitors.

Stuart Law, the West Indies coach, urged his players to learn from England after the 0-3 loss in the One-Day International series on Thursday (March 9). After being knocked out of the World Cup in 2015 in the quarterfinals by Bangladesh, England have revamped their limited-overs approach and are now one of the most formidable line-ups in the world.

"Two years ago at the World Cup, England were in a pretty big hole," Law said. "But they've gone back, changed the way they play, the way they've approached every game and it has started to work for them.

"It's an amazing transformation in two years. I'm hoping in two years' time we can sit down and say something's happening to revive West Indies cricket, something to get us competitive against these bigger teams."

Law also rued the lapsed opportunities on the field that cost them massively in the end. "The good thing about our bowling performance is we are creating opportunities," he started. "But we're just not accepting them. In the first game, we put down a player of Eoin Morgan's class and he punished us with a hundred. We've done the same today with Joe Root.

"So those are valuable lessons we must take on board and learn to accept it's an area we need to improve. There's no substitute for hard work. We've got to make sure that when those opportunities come again we do grab them."

The coach, however, was quick to point out the positives from the series that went mostly pear shaped for them. "The first glimpse of what I've got to work with and there are some very encouraging signs," he pointed out. "I thought we bowled particularly well throughout the series. Today probably wasn't our best, but the first two were good.

"With the batting, we had guys getting starts but no one going on to get big scores. That's the area we need to improve. I'm not pleased with the result but very, very happy to see some guys who have actually got something to give out there and want to be there to do it."
